channel.title: Sun Developer Network Highlights
channel.description: Product and technology highlights from the Sun Developer Network.

item.title: Sun Developer Network Announces New Membership Offerings
item.description: Joining Sun Developer Network has always meant continuous access to the tools, technologies, and expertise you need to maximize your productivity through a variety of on-line and off-line resources. As part of our pledge to continually evolve our offerings we are announcing new membership offerings that provide a range of new, exclusive services.

item.title: Sun Java Studio Enterprise Now Available
item.description: Complete developer solution for the Sun Java Enterprise System with ready-to-go, preconfigured developer tools and the Java Enterprise System together offer a complete develop-test deploy solution.

item.title: Notice Something Different About Our Masthead?
item.description: Sun Developer Network is comprised of key communities focused around Java, Mobility, and Solaris technologies. To help developers easily affiliate with one or more of these technology areas, we are aligning our branding with our community strategy. By consistently branding the site, developers gain a better experience across all our developer sites and ensure more effective integration of, and access to, information, services, and program benefits.

item.title: Portal University
item.description: Learn all about Sun Java System Portal Server through this collection of technical articles, video tutorials, learning paths, and other resources. Join the community dialog, too, by becoming a member of the Portal Server User Group and Portal Server Developer Forum.

item.title: Release 2 of the Consolidation Project
item.description: We're nearing the second release of the consolidation project we began earlier this year and we're excited about the changes we're making and how you will benefit. Take a look at what's coming and why.

item.title: Updates to the Developer Forums
item.description: This month, Sun launched the latest version of the Developer Forums at with a new look and feel. This latest version provides new functionality, allowing developers to set forum level watches which indicate that an entire forum is of interest to them. Developers can then elect to have e-mail notifications sent to them when their selected forum is updated.This service is in addition to notifications regarding community response to questions developers themselves have posted.

item.title: A New Look: java.net
item.description: Check out the new home page of : it's now even easier to find the latest content, existing projects, and active communities.

item.title: Sun Student Developer Program
item.description: Build your education and careers on Sun with more than 40 software development products.

item.title: Where Java Technology Collaboration Happens: java.net
item.description: Have you heard that Sun has recently launched java.net? This open source development site has advanced collaboration tools including project and community source code hosting, mailing lists, forums, and blogs featuring regular participation by James Gosling.

item.title: Sun's Cool Consumer Site for Java Technology: java.com
item.description: Developers can now showcase their consumer-based applications on java.com. This highly trafficked, consumer-focused site provides consumers the ability to get applications, download the Java runtime environment (JRE), and become educated about the benefits of Java technology.

item.title: Sun Developer Network Mobility Program
item.description: Looking to create, test, certify, and market Java mobility applications? Then consider membership in the Sun Developer Network Mobility Program. Membership gives you high-profile visibility to strategic partners and puts you in the elite group of developers with access to exclusive mobility content and services.

item.title: Enter to Win an Apple iPod Nano
item.description: We want to know what you think of the <a href="/prodtech/javatools/jsenterprise/tpr/">NetBeans Enterprise Pack 5.5 Preview. Give us your feedback to help us enhance this next-generation development platform, and we'll give you a chance to win an Apple iPod Nano!

item.title: Creating the Order-Tracking Web Service for Adventure Builder
item.description: With a few simple steps in Sun Java Studio Enterprise 8, you can build the Web service that's mentioned in a recent on developing Adventure Builder in Sun Java Studio Creator 2. The procedure also applies to any Web service created in WSDL.

item.title: Sun Developer Expert Assistance Program
item.description: Need some help with a Sun developer product or technology? Get help from a dedicated Sun engineer through the Sun Developer Expert Assistance Program.

item.title: InsIDE Stories Developer Contest is Closed
item.description: Thank you to all of you who participated in our Sun Java Studio Enterprise InsIDE Stories developer contest. We are still reviewing submissions, and a list of the winners will be posted on the <a href="/prodtech/javatools/jsenterprise/community/insIDEstories/index.html">InsIDE Stories contest web page by March 31.

item.title: Thinking of Switching to Our IDE? These Guides Help You Migrate
item.description: Users of Eclipse, JBuilder, and WebSphere: our latest migration guides guide you step-by-step through the process of migrating your projects to the Java Studio Enterprise IDE.

item.title: NetBeans Enterprise Pack 5.5 Preview
item.description: This preview release introduces UML modeling, XML tools, and Web services orchestration to the NetBeans community. It is available as an integrated bundle along with NetBeans IDE 5.5 Preview and Sun Java System Application Server Platform Edition 9 Beta.

item.title: Namespaces in XML Schemas, Part 2 of Two-Part Series: import and include
item.description: Learn how to create multifile XML schemas with import and include statements. Read Part 1 for the basics of namespace programming.

item.title: Marina's Blog
item.description: Read Marina Sum's blog with her latest comments and tips about our tools releases, including the .

item.title: InfoWorld: "Sun Previewing Enterprise Java Revision"
item.description: In this article, InfoWorld's Paul Krill describes our latest releases for enterprise Java technology developers.

item.title: Sun Java Studio Enterprise Wins "Best SOA IDE"
item.description: SYS-CON Media has announced that Java Studio Enterprise was voted the best IDE for Service-Oriented Architecture (SOA) development in the 2005 SOA Web Services Journal Readers' Choice Awards (see #7 in the announcement).

item.title: JDBC Data Access Via DataDirect
item.description: DataDirect Technologies provides JDBC data access in Sun Java Studio Creator, Sun Java Studio Enterprise, and Sun Java System Application Server. These products include DataDirect Connect for JDBC for use in the development phase, setting the stage for a smooth transition to production.

item.title: MonkChips Blog Favors Java Studio Enterprise
item.description: Industry analyst James Governor of RedMonk has favorably cited Java Studio Enterprise and its features in his blog: "Sun is building cool developer tool functions for online web apps into its IDEs faster than Microsoft and Eclipse? Interesting.".

item.title: Video: Application Verification Kit (AVK) for Java Studio Enterprise 8
item.description: The AVK module is now available via the Update Center in the IDE. Watch this video to learn how to use the AVK so that you can verify the correct execution of Web and Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) components in your application.

item.title: InsIDE Stories Developer Contest
item.description: Download your free copy of Sun Java Studio Enterprise, and sign up to participate in the Java Studio Enterprise 8 InsIDE Stories Contest. You could win one of 10 Sun Ultra 20 Workstations by submitting a review describing how you used the software to create an innovative solution.

item.title: Don't Miss the Sun Java Studio Enterprise 8 Tutorials
item.description: Our series of quick-start guides will smoothly guide you on how to take advantage of the powerful functionality in the IDE.

item.title: The Power of Java will hit San Francisco in May.
item.description: Attend the 2006 JavaOne conference, May 16-19 at Moscone Center in San Franciso, and hear from some of the best and brightest in the industry at the technical and BOF sessions, especially in the Java ME topic. Check the web site for the latest Conference offerings and

item.title: Java ME and NetBeans Make Sprint's Developers Productive Swiftly.
item.description: The successful Sprint Application Developers Program runs on Java ME, the Sun Java Wireless Toolkit and the NetBeans Mobility Pack. Read how Sprint and its developer community have used the triumvirate of technologies to create a thriving economic engine.

item.title: Tanjore Ravishankar, Florian Tourner and Thierry Violleau of Sun Microsystems
item.description: offer a Foretaste of Java Card Next Generation Tanjore et al will discuss Java Card Platform v2.2.2 and Java Card NG. See you at "Java Card Platform Evolution: Future Directions" (TS-3925).

item.title: Piotr Kessler and Peter Yeung of Ericsson AB
item.description: talk about the IP Multimedia Subsystem (IMS) API that provides the developer with a unified toolbox for communication services for both IP and conventional telco over wired and wireless networks. Be sure to attend their leading edge session at JavaOne.

item.title: Highlighted Mobility Sessions for JavaOne 2006
item.description: is the "must see" list of sessions. Keep this list handy when planning your week at JavaOne. How many of the 52 Java ME sessions can you attend?

item.title: Movilenio's Thriving Mobile Games Business
item.description: is based on using Java ME and the NetBeans Mobility Pack. Read how Movilenio supports their applications across more than 300 handsets from one code base.

item.title: Java ME Luminary - Hinkmond Wong of Sun Microsystems
item.description: Hinkmond Wong thinks AJAX style programming on a Java ME device is just fine. After all, it's not about the browser, just step one layer down in the stack and have a look around. Hinkmond will present code examples of how Web 2.0 services can be used with Java ME devices. Check it out.

item.title: Java Card Platform Specification 2.2.2
item.description: introduces several optional additions to the award-winning Java Card platform. These new features provide specific support for the latest contactless and ID cards. Java Card 2.2.2 also includes enhancements to align with future smart card and USIM card standards.

item.title: Java ME at JavaOne - Allen Lau of Tira Wireless
item.description: Catch the live demo "Adapting and Optimizing a Java ME Application for Global Deployment" at Java One 2006. Allen Lau of Tira Wireless will discuss development and deployment issues in the Java ME environment. A required session for anyone wanting to extend their product's potential market, from developers to CTO's.

item.title: Understanding the Web Services Subset API for Java ME
item.description: brings information on the JAX-RPC implementation for Java ME (JSR 172) to the developer community. Get the details on Web Services for Java ME, SOAP, data types and more.

item.title: Getting Started With the Information Module Profile
item.description: (IMP) introduces a profile for use in machine-to-machine communication. IMP is defined in JSR 195 and is a subset of MIDP 1.0. Get the details on the IMP model, development tools and product market.

item.title: Java ME Luminary: Randy Busch of Tira Wireless
item.description: Randy Busch VP of Products at Tira Wireless talks about mobile development and deployment. Now that you have created the "killer app", what's between you and widespread deployment on various handsets and operator networks.

item.title: Blogs and Games
item.description:
Here are some of blogs I read to keep up with mobility:

  • Full Disclosure: Enrique writes articles for us, so I'm biased.
  • FD: Hinkmond is a Sun employee.
I also feel it's my obligation to research games, so should you! Take a look at and there's lots of goodies on the mobile section of . Enjoy!

item.title: The Second Annual Casual Game Evolution Challenge, by Game Trust
item.description: Enter your Java game by March 1st and you can win $20,000 cash, a display at GDC, and a 4 Person Trip to Costa Rica! Over $50,000 in total prizes and the ultimate global publishing deal worth a lot more. Over 20 developers have already entered. Enter your game today!

item.title: Netbeans Mobility Pack 5.0
item.description: The NetBeans Mobility Pack adds to the NetBeans IDE everything needed to immediately start writing, testing and debugging Java applications for mobile phones and other Java Micro Edition (Java ME) technology-enabled devices. It includes the Java ME wireless toolkit and device emulators, so that no additional downloads are needed to start working with mobile technologies. The NetBeans Mobility Pack provides comprehensive support for the Mobile Information Device Profile (MIDP) 1.0 and 2.0, the Connected, Limited Device Configuration (CLDC) 1.1, and includes visual design tools for mobile applications, integrating mobile applications with web services. »     »

item.title: Create a MIDP Application Using Drag 'n' Drop
item.description: Interested in creating J2ME MIDP applications faster and more easily? Find out how the powerful new Visual Editor in the upcoming NetBeans Mobility Pack 4.1 IDE speeds your development time with drag and drop functionality. Read the transcript of this chat with the engineers who designed and implemented this feature for an inside look at its capabilities.

item.title: Course Announcement: Performance Optimization
item.description: May 30-June 1 -- San Jose, CA Learn techniques for optimizing application performance using Sun Studio compilers and tools on cache-based, shared-memory multiprocessor systems. 3 day class. Register now - seating is limited.

item.title: New Article: Performance Analysis Made Simple Using SPOT
item.description: An application's performance depends on a combination of hardware and software factors. There are a number of tools that can be used to extract information or collect this kind of information, but knowing which tools to pick can be tricky. This paper introduces a new tool that aims to simplify the process of performance analysis. Called the Simple Performance Optimisation Tool, SPOT is an add-on package to Sun Studio 11 for UltraSPARC based systems. Spot is part of the Cool Tools project.

item.title: New Article: Using VIS Instructions To Speed Up Applications
item.description: The advantage of using VIS instructions is that an operation can be applied to different items of data in parallel; meaning that it takes the same time to compute eight 1 byte results as it does to calculate one 8-byte results. In theory this means that code that uses VIS instructions can be many times faster than code without them

item.title: New Feature: Parallel Programming in Multi-Core Environments
item.description: December 14, 2005 New Feature: Parallel Programming in Multi-Core Environments The industry trend towards multi-core environments is accelerating. Are you ready? Learn how to maximize performance of your applications to take full advantage of the combined throughput of multi-core/multi-threaded systems.

item.title: Visit us at JavaOne!
item.description: We are at the 2006 JavaOne conference this week. Find out about the latest happenings, including session coverage, announcements, articles, blogs, photos, and more. Check out all the JavaOne action at java.sun.com/javaone/sf.

item.title: Get the Java EE 5 SDK!
item.description: Download the Java EE 5 SDK and experience the new Java EE 5 platform.

item.title: AJAX and Java Developer Resources
item.description: Get the tools, articles, advice, and resources necessary for developing feature-rich AJAX applications and let Sun help you step into the next version of the World Wide Web.

item.title: JavaScript Developer Resources
item.description: Get the JavaScript foundation that you need to build next-generation web applications using state-of-the-art tools and techniques.

item.title: AJAX, JavaScript Technology, and Sun's Support for Dynamic Web Experience: A Conversation With Eduardo Pelegri-Llopart, Greg Murray, and Vivek Nagar
item.description: Heard the buzz about AJAX and JavaScript technology? Three leaders in the field discuss Sun's efforts to help developers create highly interactive web applications that give users a sense of immediacy and speed.

item.title: The Java Persistence API: A Simpler Programming Model for Entity Persistence
item.description: See how much easier and streamlined it is to code for entity persistence with EJB 3.0 and the Java Persistence API than with the EJB 2.1 programming model.

item.title: Update: An Introduction to the Java EE 5 Platform
item.description: This update includes data from two studies that compare development on J2EE 1.4 and Java EE 5 platforms, a new section on packaging Java EE 5 platform applications, and examples with JAXB 2.0 and JavaServer Faces technology.

item.title: Top Ten Mobility Sessions for JavaOne 2006
item.description: Java ME developers have some hard choices to make due to the sheer number - over 40 - of sessions devoted to Java ME topics at this year's JavaOne conference. To help you choose, here's our list of the top ten Java ME sessions.

item.title: Top 10 Cool Stuff Destinations at the 2006 JavaOne Conference
item.description: Read about 10 sessions in the Cool Stuff track at the 2006 JavaOne conference that can inspire, motivate, and encourage your innovative use of the Java platform.

item.title: Tools: Top 10 Destinations at the 2006 JavaOne Conference
item.description: Learn about new tools and new ways to use existing tools at this year's JavaOne conference. Here's a sampling of 10 technical and BOF sessions you won't want to miss.

item.title: Top 10 Destinations for Enterprise Developers at the 2006 JavaOne Conference
item.description: Read about 10 must-see destinations and some related recommendations for enterprise developers at the 2006 JavaOne conference.

item.title: JXTA Technology Turns Five Years Old
item.description: Since 2001, JXTA technology has evolved from a research project into the industry-leading open-source peer-to-peer (P2P) technology, with more than 25,000 developers investigating compelling services and creating applications based on JXTA.

item.title: Top 10 Java SE Destinations at the 2006 JavaOne Conference
item.description: New ways to work with JFC/Swing technology, deployment strategies for Java platform applications, and updates from Effective Java author Joshua Bloch -- here are 10 must-see sessions for Java SE platform developers.

item.title: The Power of Java Hits San Francisco
item.description: Thousands of Java technology advocates, developers, and experts from across the globe will descend upon the Moscone Center from May 16 to 19, 2006, for the annual JavaOne conference. Here's a preview of the expert-led technical sessions, real-world examples, hands-on labs, previews of technical advances, and exciting events with industry leaders.

item.title: Bootstrap Interfaces Definition by Leveraging OSS Common JSR Design and Shared Entities
item.description: The OSS through Java initiative (OSS/J) is focused on the operations and business support systems (back office systems) of service providers. This article provides users with guidelines about how to extend the OSS Common API.

item.title: Programming in Real-Time Specification for Java (RTSJ): A Conversation with Distinguished Engineer Greg Bollella
item.description: Sun Microsystems Distinguished Engineer, Greg Bollella, explains how programming with Real-Time Specification for Java (RTSJ) has gotten easier and talks about the 2006 JavaOne Conference Slot Car Programming Challenge.

item.title: Realtime Form Validation Using AJAX
item.description: Using Asynchronous JavaScript and XML (AJAX) interactions, data can be validated in near real-time as the user enters information into an HTML form. This article, part of the Java BluePrints Solutions Catalog, shows how to use the power of Java and AJAX to create a simple and effective solution for form validation.

item.title: Using Java DB in Desktop Applications
item.description: Learn how to deploy Java DB, based on the Apache Derby database, within desktop Java applications. The article uses the Address Book demo to show you how to work with Java DB as an embedded database.

item.title: Conscientious Software: Part One of a Conversation with Sun Microsystems Laboratories' Ron Goldman
item.description: Ron Goldman, senior staff engineer at Sun Microsystems Laboratories, shares his vision of software that is more robust, stable, and better able to take care of itself -- conscientious software.

item.title: The Advantages of the Java EE 5 Platform: A Conversation with Distinguished Engineer Bill Shannon
item.description: Bill Shannon, Sun Microsystems distinguished engineer and specification lead for Java Platform, Enterprise Edition (Java EE), discusses the ways the Java EE 5 platform makes life easier for developers.

item.title: Managing and Monitoring Web Services in Project GlassFish
item.description: This comprehensive, three-part article shows you how to monitor and manage Web services with Project GlassFish, Sun's open-source application-server implementation of Java EE 5.

item.title: Meet Arun Gupta, Staff Engineer on Sun's Web Technologies and Standards Team
item.description: Arun Gupta discusses programming in India and the United States, the challenges of software development, Java APIs for XML Web Services Addressing (JAX-WSA), and efforts to get Sun Microsystems and Microsoft on the same page.

item.title: Understanding JDIC File-Type Associations
item.description: OS-specific tasks, JDIC's AssociationService, Association, and Action classes can now let you add or remove file-type associations in your Java technology applications.

item.title: How to Write a Helpful Bug Report
item.description: Learn how to file a bug report that will help Sun engineers focus their investigation and fix bugs more quickly.

item.title: Seeing Shouldn't Be Believing: Solving Java Puzzlers With Google's Joshua Bloch
item.description: Joshua Bloch, chief Java architect at Google, explores the mysteries of Java puzzlers and optical illusions.

item.title: Web Tier to Go With Java EE 5: Summary of New Features in JSP 2.1 Technology
item.description: This article outlines new features in JSP 2.1 technology in the Java EE 5 platform and discusses how version 2.1 has resolved the software's former incompatibility with JavaServer Faces technology.

item.title: Meet Kelly O'Hair, Senior Staff Engineer at Sun Microsystems
item.description: Sun senior staff engineer Kelly O'Hair discusses his work improving the JDK builds, his process as a developer, and the challenges of writing software.

item.title: Meet Kohsuke Kawaguchi, Staff Engineer and XML Schema Developer at Sun Microsystems
item.description: Kohsuke Kawaguchi discusses his work with XML schema languages, the cultural differences between Japan and the United States, the transition from C++ to the Java language, and more.

item.title: Web Tier to Go With Java EE 5: Summary of New Features in JavaServer Faces 1.2 Technology
item.description: Part 2 of the Java EE 5 platform series discusses new ease-of-use features in JavaServer Faces 1.2 technology, including alignment with JSP software, improved state-saving behavior, the ability to turn off component ID generation, and the new setPropertyActionListener tag.

item.title: Web Tier to Go With Java EE 5: Summary of New Features in Java Standard Tag Library (JSTL) 1.2
item.description: This second article in the series provides an overview of how JSTL 1.2, part of the Java EE 5 platform, contributes to the alignment of the JavaServer Pages and JavaServer Faces technologies in the web tier.

item.title: Introduction to the Java EE 5 Platform
item.description: Read about streamlined features and added convenience in the Java EE 5 platform that help developers improve performance, reduce development time, and get products to market sooner.

item.title: Book Review: POJOs in Action
item.description: Plain Old Java Objects (POJOs) are an attractive new way to design enterprise Java applications. Manning's new POJOs in Action shows you how to organize and encapsulate domain logic, access databases, manage transactions, and handle database concurrency using POJOs. Read more in this book review.

item.title: Developing Web Services Using JAX-WS
item.link: Read this Tech Tip by Manisha Umbarje and see how JAX-WS simplifies building and using a web service.?feed=RSS
item.description: Read this Tech Tip by Manisha Umbarje and see how JAX-WS simplifies building and using a web service.

item.title: Character Conversions from Browser to Database
item.description: Character data can go through multiple transformations as it travels from browser to database. This article describes how to avoid character data loss in the front, middle, and back end tiers of a web based application.

item.title: The Basics of GlassFish
item.description: Learn the basics of GlassFish -- what it is, why it's important, and how to get involved.

item.title: Using the Desktop API in Java SE 6 (Mustang)
item.description: Learn about Mustang's new Desktop API, which allows Java applications to interact with the default applications associated with specific file types on the host platform.

item.title: More Enhancements in Java SE 6 (Mustang)
item.description: Learn about some often-requested features that will be a hit with Mustang programmers: setting file and directory permissions, obtaining disk space, adding components to tabbed pane tabs, as well as the inclusion of the SwingWorker class.

item.title: Java Tutorial Update: J2SE 5.0
item.description: The Java Tutorial, a practical guide for programmers with hundreds of complete working examples, has recently been updated to include J2SE 5.0.

item.title: Java Technology 2005: A Year in Review
item.description: In 2005, Java technology turned ten years old, but what else happened to the platform? Plenty. Here's a quick look back.

item.title: The New Modality API in Mustang
item.description: Learn how Java SE 6 (code name Mustang) allows greater functionality for dialog boxes, supporting modeless, document, application, and toolkit modality to ease the user's experience.

item.title: SOA Best Practices: A Conversation With Sun Microsystems Distinguished Engineer Mark Hapner
item.description: Service-oriented architecture (SOA) will soon play a major role in software engineering. Sun Microsystems Distinguished Engineer Mark Hapner explores the future of SOA.

item.title: The Java SE 6 (Mustang) Holiday Quiz
item.description: How much do you know about Java Platform, Standard Edition 6, code-named Mustang? If you're just starting to peek at the exciting new Mustang betas, here's a fun way to learn about some great new features.

item.title: Realizing Strategies for Document-Based Web Services With JAX-WS 2.0
item.description: Part 3 of the series explores new features of JAX-WS 2.0 and shows how to implement some strategies to build document-driven web services on the Java EE platform.

item.title: Java Technology Fundamentals
item.description: Learn the Caret and Highlighter interfaces of text components, as well as how to access system resources and create and derive fonts.

item.title: Variable Arity Methods
item.description: Variable arity methods, sometimes referred to as varargs methods, accept an arbitrary set of arguments. JDK 5.0 adds a varargs facility that's a lot more flexible than before. Learn more in this Tech Tip.

item.title: Using AJAX with Java Technology
item.description: AJAX is a hot topic in the Java community. Learn why and see it in use with Java technology to implement an autocomplete feature on a web page.

item.title: The Next Wave of GUIs: Project Matisse and NetBeans IDE 5.0
item.description: Project Matisse creators Scott Violet and Tomas Pavek discuss how the NetBeans IDE 5.0 simplifies development of GUIs and results in a cross-platform visual designer.

item.title: Envisioning a New Language: A Conversation With Sun Microsystems' Victoria Livschitz
item.description: Principal architect Victoria Livschitz discusses her vision of Metaphors, a programming language that addresses the challenges of software development in the 21st century.

item.title: Migrating to Tiger: James Gosling and Mark Reinhold on Java 2 Platform, Standard Edition 5.0
item.description: The father of Java technology and the chief engineer of the Java Platform, Standard Edition discuss J2SE 5.0, the twists and turns of JFC/Swing, autoboxing, enhanced for loops, and more.

item.title: Mutual Authentication for Web Services: A Live Example
item.description: How do you set up secure communications among Web services for supply-chain applications? This article answers that question with a description of the implementation procedure for mutual authentication, citing the java.net project Adventure Builder as an example.

item.title: Book Review: Swing Hacks: Tips and Tools for Building Killer GUIs
item.description: Learn about multiple tips and tricks to help you make your JFC/Swing components look better and work more efficiently, from creating transparent and animated windows to using audio and more.

item.title: Customize Your JList Display
item.description: JFC/Swing's JList and JComboBox are great components for displaying object lists, but they don't always display user-friendly text by default. This article shows you how to customize how objects are displayed in JList components.

item.title: Meet Chet Haase, Java 2 Platform, Standard Edition (J2SE) Client Architect at Sun Microsystems
item.description: Chet Haase discusses what he wishes he'd learned in engineering school, how he works as a developer, and what a graphics geek does.

item.title: Free Developer Tools!
item.description: Sun is offering the award-winning Sun Java Studio Enterprise and Sun Java Studio Creator IDEs at no cost to all developers worldwide who join Sun Developer Network (SDN).

item.title: New System Tray Functionality in Mustang
item.description: The upcoming J2SE Mustang release includes a new system tray API, which allows you to embed a small icon in the OS system tray, attach a popup menu, and listen for various mouse events. This article explains how to take advantage of the two new classes that represent the system tray functionality in J2SE Mustang.

item.title: Visit the Engineers' Sandbox
item.description: This is a unique area on java.sun.com where Sun engineers and the developer community can communicate easily and directly. You will find articles, tips, code samples, opinions, and more -- provided by engineers who are interested in sharing their expertise directly with you and hearing what you have to say.

item.title: Tech Tip: The Schema Validation Framework
item.description: Sun's Neeraj Bajaj discusses the new Schema Validation Framework (SVF), also known as the Validation API, which offers advanced capabilities to efficiently validate XML against a schema.

item.title: Book Excerpt: Java Objects: From Concepts to Code
item.description: Chapter 6, "Collections of Objects," highlights the significant improvements in J2SE 5.0 to collections, which hold and organize references to other objects.

item.title: Learning Java 2D, Part 2
item.description: The Java 2D API allows you to create some stunningly high-quality graphics. This article, part 2 in a series, discusses ways to use the Java 2D libraries to manipulate and display images using the BufferedImage and VolatileImage classes, as well as techniques for performing filtering operations.

item.title: Fast Infoset and the Pragmatic SOA Approach
item.description: Fast Infoset complements the best practices of SOA -- specifically, loosely-coupled, document-based messaging. Read why Fast Infoset is a viable alternative to XML when message size and parsing performance are issues.

item.title: Book Excerpt: Java Reflection in Action
item.description: In Chapter 4, "Using Java's Dynamic Proxy," you'll learn how to use java.lang.reflect.Proxy and chain proxies, and you'll also discover the pitfalls of using Proxy.

item.title: Tech Tip: Accessing the Bean Environment in EJB 3.0 Session Beans
item.description: Deepa Singh, Sun's lead test developer for the EJB container in the Sun Java Enterprise Application Server group, discusses how Enterprise JavaBeans 3.0 (EJB 3.0) session beans declare dependencies on external resources and how dependencies can be injected into EJB 3.0 session beans.

item.title: Ensuring Speed and Openness at the Java Community Process: A Conversation With Onno Kluyt
item.description: Onno Kluyt, senior director and chair of the Java Community Process (JCP), talks about his efforts to make the JCP smoother, faster, and more open.

item.title: Easy and Efficient XML Processing: Upgrade to JAXP 1.3
item.description: The Java API for XML Processing (JAXP) 1.3, with its Validation APIs and XPath APIs, improves XML schema data type support, adds security, and increases performance.

item.title: The Next Big Thing: Service-Oriented Architecture (SOA) Takes a New Route
item.description: RouteOne's service-oriented architecture (SOA), which serves some 80% of the 22,000 auto dealerships in the United States, makes it clear that SOA is here to stay.

item.title: October is SOA/Web Services Month
item.description: We've pulled together a wide variety of content about SOA and web services, including articles, tips, white papers, code samples, and more.

item.title: Java Technology and Robotics: A Conversation With Tommy Architect Paul J. Perrone
item.description: Paul J. Perrone, chief architect of Tommy, an autonomous, unmanned Java technology-powered dune buggy that is set to compete in the semifinals of the DARPA Grand Challenge at the California Speedway, discusses the uses of Java software in robotics applications.

item.title: Meet the Engineer: Kumar Srinivasan
item.description: You've downloaded their code, commented on their technical articles, and read their blogs... Now it's your turn to meet some of Sun's most influential engineers and discover what exciting new projects they're working on and where they see Java technology going. In this installment we chat with Kumar Srinivasan, a Sun staff engineer.

item.title: New Splash-Screen Functionality in Mustang
item.description: A standard part of any GUI application, the splash screen lets the user know that the application is starting. Learn how Java SE 6 (code name Mustang) allows the application to show the splash screen even before the virtual machine starts.

item.title: Sun Microsystems Talks With Li Moore of Google
item.description: Software engineer Li Moore discusses Google's switch to J2SE 5.0: "This release is purely an improvement, in terms of language features, libraries, stability, performance, and tools."

item.title: Here Comes Tommy -- An Unmanned, Autonomous Java Technology-Powered Dune Buggy
item.description: Tommy, an autonomous, unmanned Java technology-powered dune buggy, will compete in the semifinals for the DARPA Grand Challenge at the California Speedway, on the road to a $2 million prize, starting September 27.

item.title: Internationalization: Understanding Locale in the Java Platform
item.description: To be effective, an application should respect the user's language and geographic region. Learn how to use locale-sensitive objects to customize your Java technology application with the use of language, country, and variant codes.

item.title: Creating and Using a Custom Render Kit
item.description: Learn how to use JavaServer Faces technology to create a custom render kit for the purpose of rendering markup to non-HTML clients.

item.title: Unified Expression Language
item.description: Learn about the new unified expression language for Java webtier technologes: why you need it, what you can do with it, and how you can customize it.

item.title: XML Validation and XPath Evaluation in J2SE 5.0
item.description: J2SE 5.0 provides support for validating an XML document against a schema, as well as evaluation of XPath for selecting document nodes. This article shows how to make the most of javax.xml.validation and javax.xml.xpath libraries, and it provides simple tutorials on both XML schema and XPath.

item.title: Developing an SSL-Enabled Web Application With Sun Java System Application Server 8.1
item.description: A popular security technology, SSL offers mutual authentication and message encryption in client-server communications. This article provides the steps to enable SSL in your web application and to implement SSL-enabled J2EE 1.4 security in Sun Java System Application Server 8.1 software.

item.title: Tech Tip: Learn about Locks
item.description: One of the popular features of the J2SE 5.0 libraries is the addition of concurrency utilities. Locking is one of the areas improved by the concurrency utilities. Learn more in this tech tip.

item.title: Become.com's Web Crawler: A Massively Scaled Java Technology Application
item.description: Become.com, an innovative shopping search engine, has created a Java technology web crawler that passes through 3 billion pages in seven days and may be the most sophisticated and massively scaled Java technology application in existence.

item.title: E-commerce Made Easy: eBay and the NetBeans IDE
item.description: With the NetBeans IDE and eBay's Developers Program, you can build applications for e-commerce and join the thriving community of eBay developers.

item.title: J2SE 5.0 Adoption
item.description: Thinking of migrating to J2SE 5.0 but just need a little more information? We have aggregated J2SE 5.0 articles, tips, features, white papers and more to help make the process that much easier.

item.title: Reasons to Migrate to J2SE 5.0 (Tiger)
item.description: The J2SE 1.4 platform was great, but J2SE 5.0 is even better. This article describes why developers should migrate to J2SE 5.0.

item.title: JXTA Technology Brings the Internet Back to Its Origin
item.description: JXTA technology enables a world in which billions of network services will be able to discover and interact with each other in an ad hoc and decentralized manner through a multitude of virtual Internet domains.

item.title: Getting Started With Java Data Objects (JDO): A Standard Mechanism for Persisting Plain Java Technology Objects
item.description: The Java Data Objects API provides a standard approach for achieving object persistence in Java technology by using a combination of XML metadata and bytecode enhancement. This tutorial covers the essentials.

item.title: The Network on Wheels -- Java Developers, Start Your Programming Engines!
item.description: Siemens VDO Automotive's TLA architecture transforms the automobile into an open, mobile, networked device, allowing seamless upgrades to a car's functionality at any time during the car's life cycle.

item.title: Update: Desktop Java Features in Mustang
item.description: The desktop client group describes highlights of the upcoming release of Java Platform, Standard Edition (Java SE, formerly known as J2SE). Learn more about the current status of features and bug fixes for Swing, 2D, AWT, internationalization, and deployment.

item.title: Debugging Tips for Applications Built With Sun Java Studio Enterprise 7
item.description: Learn how to best configure the debugger and compiler settings, initiate debugging sessions, and effectively debug JSP pages, servlets, and multithreaded issues.

item.title: Getting Started With the Java Rule Engine API (JSR 94): Toward Rule-Based Applications
item.description: You can create agile business applications by combining the Java platform and business rule technology, managing the business behavior outside the source code. JSR 94 provides a vendor-neutral Java platform interface to access a rule engine.

item.title: A View From Asia: A Conversation With Technology Evangelist Chuk Munn Lee
item.description: Sun Microsystems' technology evangelist Chuk Munn Lee, who has spent six years working with key Asia-Pacific ISVs to design, prototype, develop, tune, size, and benchmark their applications, presents his distinctive perspective on Java technology.

item.title: NetBeans Field Guide
item.description: NetBeans Field Guide Chapter 5, "Debugging Java Applications," shows you how to set and manage breakpoints, monitor variables, expressions, and control thread execution. Also, you'll learn how to fix code during a debugging session and view multiple debugger windows.

item.title: Charles's Corner
item.description: To stay current with Java technology, Charles Ditzel, a partner area technologist at Sun, started keeping some notes on interesting web sites he visited. Here's his most recent list.

item.title: Getting Started With JavaSpaces Technology
item.description: JavaSpaces technology is a powerful high-level tool that provides an expressive yet easy-to-learn API for building distributed and collaborative applications.

item.title: Daily Prompt for Thursday: Thursday Already?
item.description: It's Thursday already. Who would have thought that the week would go by so fast? Did you catch those "Extreme GUI Makeover" talks? Wow!

item.title: Daily Prompt: Of Beanbags, Massage, and Health Care
item.description: Good morning! If you're like me, you've probably discovered that the beanbags in the North Hall overflow area are the one of the best places to watch the general sessions.

item.title: General Session: Sharing and Eliminating the Digital Divide
item.description: Tuesday's general session drew a large crowd, as usual. John Gage, chief researcher and director of the Science Office for Sun Microsystems, opened the session by explaining that our nifty RFI Conference cards (based on Java Card technology) allow Sun to collect data on the number of people attending technical sessions and BOFs.

item.title: Congratulations Duke's Choice Award Winners
item.description: Who launched the coolest Java technology-based applications over the last year? It's a matter of opinion, but it would be hard to narrow it down to just one, two, or even 10. That's the problem that James Gosling and Scott McNealy faced in judging this year's Duke's Choice Awards, also known as the Dukies.

item.title: Welcome to the 2005 JavaOne Conference!
item.description: You've arrived at the home of the most popular Java conference in existence. And if you are returning to JavaOne, welcome back!

item.title: Coding Challenge: A Tight Contest
item.description: Over 200 entrants competed for prizes in Monday's JavaOne Conference Coding Challenge. When it came down to the final four contenders, the match was so close that even the winner didn't expect to win.

item.title: Daily Prompt: Good Information From the General Sessions
item.description: Did you see the general session yesterday? Wasn't that demonstration of the Java Studio Creator software cool?

item.title: Java Platform Update: Roadmaps & Big Directions
item.description: People who attend the JavaOne conference always come armed with the question "What's new?" They want to know what cool stuff just emerged in the Java platform so that they can start taking advantage of the latest advances in the technology.

item.title: Minimizing Memory Usage for Creating Application Subprocesses
item.description: This article explains how a Solaris application with large memory requirements can effectively create a subprocess without unduly running out of memory or creating a deadlock. It also explores a related issue of how application memory is committed in the Solaris OS as opposed to other operating systems such as Linux.

item.title: Purchase Sun Training and Receive a Free Standard Sony PSP
item.description: Receive a Sony PlayStation Portable with the purchase of selected training from Sun, or participation in a Solaris Certification Coaching program.

item.title: Sun Uses Your Software Documentation Feedback
item.description: Discover the major findings of surveys and other feedback sources, and see how documentation groups are responding to user suggestions. Using the Feedback tab, provide input to help us develop documentation that meets your needs more effectively.

item.title: Survey on the Solaris 10 OS for Desktops
item.description: Are you using the Solaris 10 OS on your desktop? Please take a moment and tell us about your experience with Sun Java Desktop System or CDE. What do you like, and what needs improvement? Then we can build an even better desktop that fits your needs.

item.title: OpenSPARC T1 Version 1.0.1 Ready for Download
item.description: This source code is being made available so that ideas around the multithread concepts can be explored more freely and openly. Join the the OpenSPARC-T1 project -- membership is now open to all.

item.title: Solaris Containers Technology Architecture Guide (pdf)
item.description: This Sun BluePrints article provides suggestions for designing system configurations using powerful tools associated with Solaris Containers, guidelines for selecting features suited to the user's needs, advice on troubleshooting, and a comprehensive consolidation planning example.

item.title: Working with Solaris Containers and the Solaris Service Manager (pdf)
item.description: Read about technologies inside the Solaris 10 OS that enable administrators to determine the current state of the computing environment. This Sun BluePrints article explains how users can put these new features to work, simplifying the use of the Solaris OS for consolidation efforts.

item.title: Tell Us What You Like or Don't Like About BigAdmin
item.description: We're doing a survey of system administrators, so please submit your feedback. (After your submission, you'll need to respond to a confirmation email).

item.title: Developer Resources for AJAX and Java Technology
item.description: Get the tools, articles, advice, and resources necessary for developing feature-rich AJAX applications and let Sun help you step into the next version of the World Wide Web.

item.title: Developer Resource Center for JavaScript Technology
item.description: Get the JavaScript foundation that you need to build next-generation web applications using state-of-the-art tools and techniques.

item.title: CoolThreads Selection Tool
item.description: The CoolThreads Selection Tool (cooltst) applies simple heuristics to determine whether a workload from one platform is a reasonable candidate for Sun Fire T2000/T1000 servers.

item.title: Community-Submission: Converting a ksh Function to a ksh Script
item.description: A BigAdmin reader describes how to create a script that behaves as both an executable script and a ksh function.

item.title: Sun Desktop Manager Tutorial
item.description: Sun Desktop Manager 1.0 is a component of the new Sun Ray Software 4 release. Learn how to set up a simple Sun Desktop Manager configuration based on the Sun Java Enterprise System Directory Server, version 5.2.

item.title: Desktop Management With Sun Ray Software
item.description: Sun Desktop Manager 1.0, a component of the new Sun Ray Software 4 product, provides capabilities to manage desktops in a thin client environment. This document offers instructions for setting up the software and examples of its usage, as well as extensive screen captures.

item.title: Create a Web Service Using NetBeans 5.0 IDE and Consume the Service with Sun Java Studio Creator 2 IDE
item.description: See an end-to-end solution for developing a web service “from scratch.” Start with the NetBeans 5.0 IDE and to create a web service, and then consume it in a portlet or web application client built with the Sun Java Studio Creator 2 IDE. By Beth Stearns and John Baker.

item.title: What to know more about internationalization?
item.description: <a href="/prodtech/javatools/jscreator/learning/tutorials/2/internationalizingapps.html">Understanding Internationalization, which provides background information to help you develop an internationalized application. Then move on to <a href="/prodtech/javatools/jscreator/learning/tutorials/2/demonstrating_i18n.html">Creating an Internationalized Application, which provides step-by-step instructions for building an application that supports multiple languages.

item.title: Follow Sun Senior Staff Engineer Craig McClanahan at JavaOne.
item.description: Craig was co-lead for the JavaServer Faces 1.0 specification, and the originator of the Struts Framework. He's now a key architect of the Java Studio Creator IDE and is spending a lot of time lately on the road, presenting Java Studio Creator and JavaServer Faces at conferences all over the world. He hopes to get some time to blog during the event.

item.title: Stay Up-to-Date with Update 1
item.description: Java Studio Creator, Update 1 changes the bundled application server from Sun Java Application Server 8.1 to 8.2, upgrades the bundled database from PointBase to the open source Java Database 2 (Derby), and includes all previous hot fixes.

item.title: The Learning Curve Journals
item.description: Catch up with Walter Hardy. An independent web development consultant using Java Studio Creator, he's written several new columns about his experience with the IDE and JavaServer Faces components, AJAX, and Web services.

item.title: Migrating to Java Studio Creator, Update 1
item.description: Find out how to use the upgrade feature that helps you migrate your user settings and data from Java Studio Creator 2 to the new version, Update 1.

item.title: Writing Custom Components for Java Studio Creator Part 1: Developing a Component Library
item.description: This article by Edwin Goei and Beth Stearns was written for component vendors who want to develop a simple complib that contains components and a converter.

item.title: Writing Custom Components for Java Studio Creator Part 2: Design-Time Considerations
item.description: Get guidelines for writing custom components for Java Studio Creator 2 users in this article by Edwin Goei and Beth Stearns.

item.title: Using the New AJAX Buy Now Button Sample Component in the Sun Java Studio Creator 2 IDE
item.description: Get the podcast and learn how to use the AJAX Buy Now Button sample component in Sun Java Studio Creator 2 IDE applications. Watch Steve Fleming's podcast and read the accompanying article by Jayashri Visvanathan, Steve Fleming, and Beth Stearns.

item.title: How to Retrieve Binary Data, a tech tip
item.description: New for Update 1, this tech tip and accompanying project shows you how your web application can be designed to upload binary files, such as image files, into a database, so users can retrieve them for viewing.

item.title: Uploading and Retrieving Text Files by Sakthivel Gopal
item.description: Create web applications that allow your users to upload text files to a database and then later retrieve and view them.

item.title: Deploying to WebSphere from the Sun Java Studio Creator 2
item.description: Learn the steps needed to prepare a WAR file exported from the Sun Java Studio Creator 2 IDE for deployment to the IBM WebSphere Application Server versions 5.x and 6.x in this tech tip by Roman Mostyka.

item.title: The Sun Java Studio Creator 2 Application Model by David Botterill
item.description: The Java Studio Creator 2 visual web application development tool (IDE) employs a conceptual reference, or application model, that describes the design and runtime makeup of a web application built with the IDE. Learning how this model relates to specific parts of a web application gives you an understanding of the structure of web applications produced by the Java Studio Creator IDE, and enables you to take full advantage of the capabilities of the tool.

item.title: Binding Standard Data Table Components to Database Tables
item.description: Learn the steps needed to bind standard Data Table components to database tables in Sun Java Studio Creator 2 IDE by Chary Kanaparthi.

item.title: Get the New Sample AJAX Components!
item.description: New and improved Java BluePrints AJAX sample components are now available! Get them one of two ways: in the early access version of the Java BluePrints solutions catalog or with the visual web development tool. Current users can connect to the update center to automatically download the cool new components built on JavaServer Faces, including Rich Text Area, Rating, and a Buy Now Button integrated with PayPal. Get complete descriptions, how-to articles, and downloads on the Java Studio Creator page.

item.title: Java Studio Creator training is coming to a city near you!
item.description: Learn to develop visual web applications and portlets in just three days. You'll use the tool's bundled JavaServer Faces components to build applications that access a database, EJB components, and Web services. The course also covers portlet design, internationalizing and localizing applications, and AJAX technology. In the hands-on lab you'll you'll build a multi-tiered e-commerce application.

item.title: Flavors of CRUD tutorial projects against all supported databases by Sakthivel Gopal
item.description: Check out Sakthi's weblog entry on Java Studio Creator 2 projects built while exercising the Performing Inserts Updates and Deletes Tutorial against all of the supported databases using the bundled Sun JDBC Drivers, Oracle (8iR3, 9iR2, and 10gR1), Microsoft SQL Server 2000 SP3, Sybase ASE 12.5, and IBM DB2 V8.1.

item.title: Sun IT Treasury - Save $1 Million
item.description: Learn how Java Studio Creator helped Sun Microsystem's own financial organization save over one million dollars in IT costs and expenses.

item.title: You asked for it: Tutorials now offered in PDF format
item.description: The three Getting Started tutorials are now available in pdf format. The pdf provides a nice version of the tutorials that you can print and work with offline. Stay tuned...we're working on providing all tutorials in pdf format soon.

item.title: Component Catalog
item.description: Take a look at all the components included with Java Studio Creator, with brief descriptions of each component and running examples of some. <a href="/prodtech/javatools/jscreator/reference/code/samplecomps/componentcatalog.html">Check it out!</a>

item.title: Technical Tip: Exporting Database or EJB Applications to the Sun Portal Server
item.description: Learn the steps needed to export database and EJB applications from the Sun Java Studio Creator 2 IDE to Sun Portal Server 6.3.1/7.0 in this tech tip by Srinivas Gundeaboina.

item.title: Tutorial: Using the AJAX Map Viewer Component
item.description: Build a JavaServer Faces web application that uses the sample AJAX Map Viewer component by importing the Java BluePrints AJAX components into the Java Studio Creator IDE, then use Google's free map service API to create a custom map. The map includes marker text and a flag that pinpoints an address entered by the user.

item.title: Tutorial: Using the AJAX Progress Bar Component
item.description: Build a web application that uses the sample Java BluePrints AJAX Progress Bar component by importing the Java BluePrints AJAX components into the Java Studio Creator IDE, then create a web application that has three pages. The first page has a button that navigates to the second page, which contains a progress bar. The progress bar increments to 100%, then navigates to the third page.

item.title: Binding to MySQL in Java Studio Creator
item.description: Discover how to use MySQL within Java Studio Creator. Walk through the installation, adding an example database, setting up a MySQL data source, and creating a demo web application.

item.title: Technical Article: Working with the Tree Component and Tree Node Actions by Sherry Zhou and Beth Stearns
item.description: Learn how to use tree node information and, by following along with the Garden Tree sample application, find out how to handle tree node actions using a single method.

item.title: New chapters available now: Java Studio Creator Field Guide
item.description: This is the definitive guide to Java Studio Creator 2. Leading Java technology instructors and consultants Gail and Paul Anderson help you use the IDE to simplify and accelerate your entire development process. Published by Sun Microsystems Press. <a href="/prodtech/javatools/jscreator/learning/bookshelf/index.html">Download it free, today</a>.

item.title: Technical Article: Conditional Validation in Java Studio Creator 2 by Matthew Bohm
Technical Tip: Retrieving Binary Data by Sakthivel Gopal
item.description: This tech tip and accompanying project shows you how your web application can be designed to upload binary files, such as image files, into a database, so users can retrieve them for viewing.

item.title: Technical Tip: How to Avoid RowSet Display Synchronization Errors by Chary Kanaparthi
item.description: Find out how to avoid synchronization errors between the Query Editor and the Visual Designer that may occur when you modify a RowSet in the Query Editor.

item.title: Technical Article: Using CachedRowSet and CachedRowSetDataProvider in the Sun Java Studio Creator 2 IDE by Beth Stearns and Joel Brown
item.description: Learn how to programmatically insert rows into a database table using the CachedRowSet method to facilitate data binding to components and, with the CachedRowSetDataProvider method, to control cursor position in the CachedRowSet.

item.title: The Learning Curve Journals: Entry 2 by Walter Hardy
item.description: If you're a developer learning Java using the Java Studio Creator IDE you'll appreciate this series of journals by Walter Hardy. An independent web developer, Walter has wanted to up-level his career and offer his clients the Java web apps they've been asking for. In his second journal entry, Walter delves into <a href="/prodtech/javatools/jscreator/community/journals/hardy/journal2.html">Java Technology Essentials</a>.

item.title: Technical Tip: Configuring the Number of Rows in a Table Component
item.description: Java Studio Creator engineer Chary Kanaparthi shows you how to configure a table component to display a different number of rows than specified by the default. When the application redisplays the Table component (such as when it is opened at a later point in the application) it will not revert to the default number of rows.

item.title: Review: Java Studio Creator 2 Offers Across the Board Improvement by Dick Wall
item.description: "Java Studio Creator presents a manageable interface that has the functionality to carry out the task at hand without a developer getting lost in thousands of different options and views." Find out why this reviewer says, "It is a development tool that I keep coming back to...for Web UI development at work and at home."

item.title: Technical Tip: How to Navigate Between Pages in a Portlet Application
item.description: Some components behave differently in the portlet environment, which means that you must implement page navigation differently when developing a portlet application than when developing a web application. This technical tip describes how you can specify page navigation in a portlet using several different components: Hyperlink and Breadrumbs, Tree, or Alert.

item.title: Technical Article: Introduction to JavaServer Faces Components
item.description: Find out the difference between customizing an existing JavaServer Faces standard component and building a new, custom component. Discover why you might want to build your own components, plus what you must keep in mind if you decide to do so. This article also provides steps for including these components in applications you are developing with Java Studio Creator 2.

item.title: Weblog: Rough Guide for Editing Themes in Java Studio Creator 2
item.description: In his weblog, Java Studio Creator engineer, Gregory Murphy, explains themes, and steps you through the process of editing the contents of the default theme so that you can create a unique look and feel for your web applications.

item.title: Technical Tip: How to Rename a Default Package by Devananda Jayaraman
item.description: Find out how to manually edit the project file in Java Studio Creator to change the name of your default package in this technical tip.

item.title: The Learning Curve, Journal 1: Exploring Java Technology and the Java Studio Creator IDE by Walter Hardy
item.description: Find out why independent web developer Walter Hardy is switching from Macromedia to Java in this first installation of The Learning Curve Journals for Java Studio Creator 2.
